intro: Sida chacoensis, commonly known as the Chaco sidia, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly found in Argentina, Paraguay, and Bolivia. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its soft, hairy stems and lobed leaves. The plant produces small, yellow flowers that are often clustered in inflorescences, and it is known for its ability to thrive in arid and semi-arid environments. Sida chacoensis is also valued for its medicinal properties and has been used in traditional herbal remedies.
